Thanks for making this walktrough of how to make an H1 and H2 display monochromatic hologram, okay said that im little saad to see some basic mistakes such as;
1, the object beam is not coherent only the reference beam is, thats simply not the case, the fact is if both beams would be deond the lasers coerentlength you would not recort any inteferencepattern meaning you would have nothing atleast not a hologram, here we must understant that the coherenthlength dictates the debth of the hologram.
2, a hologram is not a sterioscopic pictor but its an holistic recorting of light first its sircoler and not linear like the steriographic tecnic, thoe we can make holographic multiplex steriogtams this with more that just two pictours "steriogram" actoly this holographic multiplex steriographys resolution is in the hundres of pictours, so its about axes and resolution a hologram has an extream high 3d resolution with parelaxes in both all directions and not like steriography only in x or y, with holographic tecnics we can even recort an 360⁰ and box holograms with full vision paralax.
There is a reason its caled a HOLOGRAM and not an steriogram, steriograms are like sterio audio recording using an two chanel recording system where holo meaning holistic, gram meaning remaking or recorting so its a holistic recording a Hologram.

WRONG, YOU LOSE ANGLES OF VIEW! So sorry you are dealing with OLD SCHOOL knowledge of holographic plates. Your comment that if you cut a small square piece of the holographic plate that you would still be able to see the entire object in that small cutout piece of the holographic plate is INCORRECT. And this is simple as a thought exercise. Now imagine that you bounced a laser beam at a coffee cup that is centered to the middle of a photographic film that you are capturing the image on. Now imagine that you have to look through the photographic film, lets say that the film was like a 12" inch square. And the 12"sq film and the coffee cup are stationary and cannot be moved. Only you the viewer who is behind the film can only move: up/down/side-to-side/diagonally, so that your angles of view to see the centered coffee cup changes. Let's say that you cannot look through the holographic film unless you poke a peep hole through it first. If you poked a small hole at the top portion of the film so that you can now peek through the film and look slightly downward to see the top of the coffee cup, but from the hole at the top of the film you cannot see the bottom of the coffee cup because the light hitting the bottom of the coffee cup is blocked by the coffee cup. And in order to see the bottom of the stationary coffee cup you would have to view the coffee cup by poking another peep hole at the bottom of the 12"sq stationary film to see the bottom of the coffee cup. So, what you are missing is angles of view. If you were to cut a 12" X 1"strip of the top of the holographic film you would ONLY see the top of the cup side-to-side as if you are looking at a coffee cup sitting on top of a wooden table, but unless you could look up through the bottom of the table you would never be able to see the bottom of the coffee cup. WHAT YOU WOULD LOSE IF YOU CUT A PIECE OF THE 12"x12" SQUARE holographic plate is ANGLES-OF-VIEW. By cutting the original holographic film YOU LOSE ANGLES OF VIEW.

Great video. But it needs a minor correction:
Just because each point on the holographic film contains information about the complete object, does not mean when cutting a piece from the film, you still can reconstruct the object. It just means that each point on the film contains information in the form of an amplitude that is derived from the sum of all amplitudes of light of various phase being reflected off all points of the object.
“Holographic” pyramid: conceptual errors and didactic potential. Look: http://dx.doi.org/10.1590/1806-9126-rbef-2017-0186
Unfortunately this makes no sense to someone who doesn't have a solid understanding of light physics lol

Thank you so much for stating the fact that for holograms like this; for each division of the whole, that the whole is contained within each division.

This fact is one of the rarest things demonstrable, about some very special things, such as a single member of a species still has all the information about that species.

Or a single instance of an electron, still has all the properties of all electrons.

Possibly there is such a relationship with many other intangible relationships that may or do exist all through the universe....and teaching about things like this really does inspire one to wonder about all the other types which exist in this, or similar beautiful ways.

at 2:21 She says that the object beam is not coherent, which is completely false. It is absolutely coherent with the reference beam, and that's the only way it's able to create an interference pattern. if the object beam were not coherent, no interference would form at all, and there'd be no hologram. The beam has a coherence length longer than any path length difference of light reaching the film.
how exactly does it work that you can see the entire image in a small fragment of the entire picture AND the entire picture on the entire picture?

I like your upper lip! ;p

The object beam is absolutely still coherent.  Both beams must be coherent (that is they have deterministic phase relationship with each other) to be able to produce an interference pattern on the holographic film.  The beam reflecting off of the object is extremely complex, but it is coherent with respect to the reference beam.
What would it look like if the reference beam changed in frequency?
